Title: An almost perfect film
Review:
This is one of the biggest hits of the year, so I'm not going to waste time with a description of the plot.

Let's begin.

Basically, the first twenty minutes are boring, then Tom Hanks gets on the plane, and the moment the plane begins to experience trouble, this film is a technical masterpiece right up until he leaves the island. Yes, sorry, he does get off the island, but this shouldn't come as a surprise since the trailer ruined that shock before the film even opened.

Tom Hanks is washed ashore and the next hour and a half results in one of the most amazing pieces of film making ever. Tom Hanks is brilliant in what could have been a one dimensional role; Robert Zemeckis directions with another firm hand; and, above all, I got really attached to that damn volleyball, so kudos to the film makers on that, too.

But, then he gets off the island, and it's another twenty/thirty minutes until the film finally resolves itself - Hanks has to get back to the girl he left waiting for him, even though it's been four years, played by Helen Hunt. Now, I like Helen Hunt, she's a fine actress, but she's terribly overrated. If someone could tell me why she won an Oscar for As Good As It Gets, I would like to know because every character she ever plays, regardless of the film, is the Jamie Buchman character from Mad About You. She's wasted here, with hardly more than a cameo, and the film suffers as a result.

The trailer ruined what could have been a perfect film, since there's no surprise that he gets off. But the film almost collapses on it's own with a weak opening act, and a terrible third. This film would have been far better off if the hanks character had been on the plane in the very begginning, and the movie ending with him getting off. Hell, even though 3/4 of the movie was spent on the island, the film makers could have shot an extra half hour of stuff, slapped it in, rather than the weak first and third act, because everything on the island is perfect.

The rest is weak, contrived, Hollywood tripe.

All in all, a good movie, that is great if you fastforward the first twnety minutes and shut it off after he gets off the island. Hanks deserved an Oscar, hands down. And so did that damn volleyball.

I was impressed with how the film makers managed to surpress any shark attacks, since it has become a Hollywood cliche. I would love to give this film a 10/10, but due to the first and third acts, I can only give it an 8. Still, highly recommended, but I recommend having the remote in your hand.

Title: One of the most memorable films of the 2000s
Review:
"Cast Away" is a film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Tom Hanks.

One of the most surprising aspects of "Cast Away" is the interpretation of Tom Hanks.

His performance is extraordinary, and his commitment to the role of an isolated man on a desert island conveys authenticity and emotion.

One of the things I liked most was the narration which focuses on Chuck's struggle for survival, but also explores his transformation as an individual. Isolation and loneliness force him to confront himself and re-evaluate the priorities of life.

Another element that deserves praise is the soundtrack of Alan Silvestri that helps create an engaging atmosphere.

In conclusion "Cast Away" is one of the most memorable films of the 2000s.

Title: Made me belly laugh - later I heard that bellies shouldn't laugh at this movie
Review:
I remember watching this in the cinema when I was just 20 years old. My friend and I found the part where Tom Hanks is talking to Wilson, the volleyball, pretty funny. We even held our bellies in belly laughter; it was hysterically funny to us for some reason that I've forgotten this 18 years later.

The next evening I was reading the newspaper at my night shift gas station attendant job when I saw an editorial in the Ottawa Sun about the movie. The writer was furious about two young men laughing during the movie The Castaway that he wrote a scathing article about the incident and the impudence of the youth and the lack of respect for serious movies.

I didn't feel particularly scolded; I just felt that this man needs to calm down or perhaps get a hemorrhoid removed.

In fact, the friend I brought with me to the cinema was having a hard time at University and the movie was a good way to cheer him up.

The Ottawa Sun columnist was so upset by the incident that he actually wrote a follow up a few days later. Maybe he didn't have a lot of things to write about.

I imagine that he was thinking this during the movie,

"Those impudent ingrates!!! My society makes entertaining serious movies to shape up these rebellious, slovenly, backwards youths and they scoff in my face?! Laughing during the movie? During my viewing time no less?! I am a columnist! You will pay two teenagers! I'll write one scathing article to fix you right the heck up! No, not one, two really scathing articles! Two articles later and you will be so sorry!

Title: Realistic film, but not "Lost'
Review:
Believe it or not,until last night,I had never seen this movie. I'd seen snippett's of it on The Oscars and other places but I just hadn't seen it. I made one attempt about 2 years ago,checking the movie out of library but the copy had been grossly damaged. Finally though,my brother stopped by with his copy and we watched it. He's seen it several times.

My overall impression after watching it was,"Wow,what an amazing story". The story of a man who has little time for his very understanding wife who obviously loves him like crazy. Who takes off just before Christmas of 1995 on doomed flight that will alter his life forever.

The scene of the mayhem that ensues in side of the plane was very well done,as were the scenes of Hanks' character surviving the angry seas. Finally he arrives safely to a deserted island. Where for the next 1500 days his will to live is put to the test.

He finds food,makes shelter,works like a caveman to create fire and basically just learns the art of true survival. All the while the only other thing keeping him going is the antique pocket-watch given to him by his wife before he boarded the plane. Her picture in the watch gives him hope that he'll return to her someday soon.

After 4 years pass,he's still surviving but his mind has drifted into a state of altered reality. He's taken to painting a face on a soccer ball (with his own blood) and nameing it "Wilson",as it says on the ball. "Wilson" becomes his best friend.

Finally (and quite amazingly) near the end of this,another piece of the plane washes up on shore and he uses it as a sail for a raft he builds. It's actually a credit to Hanks' acting when "Wilson" falls overboard into the ocean and floats away,Hanks actually makes us feel his loss for this imaginary friend.

Upon being rescued and getting home,he discovers his wife and friends gave up on his return. Se's remarried with children and his friend informs him that they had a funeral and wake for him.

His now ex-wife realizes she shouldn't have listened to her friends & family who said she should just "let him go". Which gives us a slightly "hollywood" scene of her calling to him & chasing after him in the rain as he's driving off. They still love each-other but the damage is done.

With the life he knew gone he's now at a complete loss as to what he's supposed to do with it now. The ending really doesn't provide a clear-cut answer but merely hints at it. I can only guess the question to ask by the ending is,"What would I do if all this happened to me"? I give ten stars because the movie is simply that engaging,moving even a bit suspenseful (if you've never seen it. The scenery is breathtaking as well and the whole movie is worth the time to watch. (END)

Title: hank's best role...
Review:
...since 'Bachelor Party.' no, actually I'm in agreement with pretty much everyone else. this was an enjoyable movie. not only was I glad that a movie was made around this subject, but also for the fact that audiences are into it. there are a few intense scenes, especially the airplane crashing into the ocean and Chuck trying to retrieve Wilson while pulling his raft in the middle of the ocean. along with "the Perfect Storm", I appreciate the moments in which the main characters' attempt the seemingly fool-hardy task of defeating the ocean. in "cast away" Chuck ultimately succeeds, while Clooney & crew failed. the lack of a musical score on the island and only focusing on wild sounds was a clever trick by Zemeckis. I was a bit disappointed that huge gaps in Chcuk's stay on the island occurred, but this wasn't Robinson Crusoe. both Hanks & Hunt are sickenly appealing, but Hanks has the ability to make the viewer identify with his character. I constantly found myself asking how I would be able to survive in this situation, and I very much doubt I'd survive as long as Chuck did. anyways, this movie is a much better collaboration between Zemeckis & hanks than "forrest gump" which stunk to high heaven.

Title: Some good moments but ultimately goes nowhere
Review:
After the good reception in the US, I looked forward to seeing this film when it opened here in Australia. In the end, I was disappointed.

The first part of the film builds the character of Chuck (Tom Hanks), and shows us his relationship with his girlfriend Kelly (Helen Hunt). I thought that a lot of the dialogue in this section (especially in the plane before the crash) was poorly timed and delivered, and didn't really contribute much to the story.

The crash scene itself is excellent, and the middle section of the movie (on the island) is enjoyable. The use of an 'imaginary friend' to allow dialogue on the island (and to show the character trying to cope with the loneliness and avoid madness) was novel and effective.

However I felt it went downhill when he returned to civilisation. There were many unanswered questions (why try and tow the raft when he had oars? If the package was so important to his will to live, why leave it unexplored until the end?) and an unsatisfactory examination of the effect of Chucks return on the relationship between him, Kelly, and her new husband.

In all I felt it was a fairly average movie, with some missed opportunities and fairly good performance from Tom Hanks. I'd recommend waiting for it on video.

Title: I just can say: wow!
Review:
Robert Zemeckis did it again! He never stops to impress me! Man, this guy is talented! What a great director.

And what a great film! I loved this movie. I laughed, I cried, and I enjoyed the film.

Certainly one of my favorite movies of the year. My second favorite, because Erin Brockovich is still my fave.

But man, this film was great. Very intelligent, with great acting, funny stuff, and lots of drama.

I loved Wilson! The interaction between Tom Hanks and Wilson was perfect. I cried when he got lost. I cried a lot! And I still can't believe it. I cried for a volleyball!!!

The ending of the film wasn't bad! It was great!!! The wings, all the symbolism. Everything! I rate this film with 10 stars.

Oh, and the music! Even though most of the film passed out with no music, the moments with music were great! I don't know yet who was the composer for this film, but he did his best! And excellent job.

What else? I don't know what else to say... Oh, I kept crying even when the film was already finished. I was walking with my mom to the car, and I was crying.

One more thing, the scene of the airplane crash was great! Wicked, horrible, terrific! Arrrggghhh, I loved this film!

One of the years best. I hope it gets nominated for the Oscars. I guess we'll have to wait and see.

Title: Some points about the ending

Title: The real message of the movie is NOT about being stranded on an island
Review:
If you haven't seen the movie, don't read this discussion, because my discussion might give a hint to the ending of the movie.

The real message is you shouln't treat your professional life more importantly than you personal life.

When Tom Hanks was having a joyous dinner with his girlfriend, family, and close friends, he was interrupted by a telephone call from his company. He was told he had to leave and travel half way around the world to fix a problem for his company.

Next thing he knows, Tom Hanks was stranded by himself on a island. He couldn't leave the island for years.

When Tom Hanks finally got back to the real world, the love of his life (Helen Hunt) has already married to another man. (Ironically Helen Hunts was married to a dentist, and Tom Hanks had to remove a bad tooth when he was on that island)

I was so touched by the scene when Tom Hanks went to Helen Hunt's house for the first time, after Hanks came back from the island.

They had soooo much love between them. But so much has changed since the last time they saw each other, when they were having that dinner when that phone call came, and when they exchanged Christmas presents in that car, just before they said good bye. Helen Hunts has already married to another man and they already have a baby.

They still love each other so much. And they know they were meant to be husband and wife. But they know that they couldn't turn back the clock.

Remember the scene when they remove the baby seat from the car?

The message of the movie is your love ones are more important and precious than your job and career.

I was so emotionally touched by the last 15 minutes of the movie, I almost cried.

Title: Sadly, not all can appreciate this movie...
Review:
I saw Cast Away for the 2nd time tonight and I was amazed at what I had missed the first time. Everything made me love it even more than I did before. Unfortunately, not everyone in the theater shared my sentiment. Several left with only 15 minutes to go and one idiot even yelled how much the movie "sucked." To ignorant people like these, I suppose Wilson was just a volleyball, not an object to represent Chuck's rational side and will-power survive on the island. His drifting away signaled that Chuck no longer needed him; he had fought on and now he was to be rescued. Many griped that Chuck should have opened the winged package. Why? Here was his FedEx instincts at work and his commitment to never turn his back on time. Who cares what was inside?! Anyway, I could go on forever about all the symbolism in this movie, but I'll give that a rest.

Everything in Cast Away was superb: the acting, the script, the awesome cinematography, and of course, Bob Zemeckis's wonderful direction. Tom Hanks should at least be nominated for Best Actor, but I doubt he'll get it. In any case, his brilliant work really carried the movie when there wasn't much verbal communication.

Well, if you're reading this and have seen the movie, I hope you can relate to what I am saying. If you haven't seen it, then definitely go, but only if you can appreciate this movie for its depth and presentation of the relentlessness of the human spirit. Otherwise, you are likely to be disappointed.

Title: What's the point of cliff-notes trailers???
Review:
Why, oh why did they give the whole movie away in the trailers and TV commercials? What could possibly have been the point? To get us to see it? I didn't need that. I was going to see it after viewing the first trailer months ago...you know the one where he lands on the island and yells "Hello,...anybody!!" and then it fades to black. That's all I needed. I was hooked right there. Yeah, Tom Hanks was great. Yeah, it was a good story, so what.

My whole experience of this movie was a big let down, because I knew what was going to happen. I'm sure others who say they didn't really enjoy the movie are feeling the disappointment stemming from this knowledge, as well. The only thing I didn't know for sure was what was going to happen after he got back to civilization...but I had a pretty good idea, and I was right, which was another disappointment. Predictability kills a movie for me. I don't want to know what's going to happen before I see it, and I certainly don't want the whole movie laid out for me in the trailer, as this one was...ridiculous.

I still can't believe it. If you've seen all the trailers for this movie, as I did, there was really no reason to see the movie in the theatre...because you've already seen it, in condensed form. Of course, by just seeing the trailers you don't get the full range and impact of emotion and the subtle nuances that drive the plot forward, and of course you miss the cinematography that makes the movie great to look at, as well as the remarkable physical transformation of Tom Hanks' character, but if you want to know what this movie is all about, and I do mean "all about", then the trailers are all you need.

I kept waiting for something to happen...some twist in the plot. Maybe he would come back and be unable to re-acclimate himself to civilization, or something...anything. But from the moment he came back, the movie sank into dismal predictability, heart-wrenching, yes, but predictable, just the same.

This seems to be a nasty trend in trailers, lately. Perhaps the rationale is the more they show in the trailer, the more will come to see the movie. Faulty logic, if you ask me. Once you have the fish on the hook, you don't keep throwing bait at it.

The volleyball had a better role.....

Why does hollywood have to constantly dole out symbolic garbage? EVERY scene is this movie is a cheap attempt at profoundness..... Thanks for nothing......

The cave men were able to make fire faster...... rubbing a couple of sticks together when you had the flashlight lense, and this guy is supposed to be some upper up smart guy in FEDex?

A port-a-potty ? give me break.... he had the rescue raft there on the island with him, yes it had holes in the inflatable part but the bottom was intact and would have made a better sail......

What happened to the toothache?

What happened to the ring box he gave to Helen "I have 10 seconds of screen time" Hunt?

My advice: If you have to see this film, let a friend rent it and then only when it's on the $00.99 shelf.......

Title: Another gem from Hanks!
Review:
I came out of the theater wondering how Mr. Hanks could have condensed so much emotion and depth into what potentially seemed an empty movie. I think it's his best work since Dragnet. People compare his everyman style to the great Jimmy Stewart, and rightly so. Whenever I saw Hanks working his magic, for example in the charming scenes with the volleyball, you could see the mantle of 'America's Actor' being passed from Stewart to Hanks. I have'nt seen that kind of chemistry between an actor and non-speaking prop since Hanks' previous triumph, Turner and Hooch.

The direction captured the isolation of Hanks and his surroundings, whilst keeping an understated feel. Definitely Zemeckis' best job since Death Becomes Her and Forrest Gump. My one gripe being that the most memorable part of the movie was the crash sequence. I had hoped that the director could have matured, and not rely on special effect action sequences to carry his movies. And the dialogue was adequate too. I could'nt decide between this and Boyles Jnr's other standout, Entrapment.

There was support from Hunt and Noth: I thought that their acting on the periphery, provided the necessary distance that enhanced Hanks' realistic portrayal of solitude. The same effect that Tawney Kitaen and Adrian Zmed had on Hanks in Bachelor Party. The 'far-off' co-acting in both films provided the chance for Hanks to shine in his solo star role amongst the driftwood.

The ending, when we find Hanks back in civilization, I felt did'nt keep with the tone and pace of the film. Although we are now used to the heart-warming rousing finales of Hanks' movies, who could forget the close-out of Splash, I would have preferred to have seen Hanks see out the film still on the island, with the volleyball.

In closing I would rate Cast Away quite well against the other 'stranded on an island' movies I have seen. Hanks' project deals with the issues of alienation and survival, whilst not losing sight of the potential of fate that can rescue people from isolation and put them back into a more favorable position. Similar to what $1 million did for Richard Hatch after the Survivor TV series. And not to point all the credit to Hanks, seen in the box-office returns for Cast Away, I do hope that his co-star in Big, Jared Rushton received a few points after showing Hanks the potential for a 'lost in the wilderness' vehicle, after he starred in a not too dissimilar picture, A Cry In The Wilderness.

A 'twerp cinema' rating of four.

Title: Cast Away
Review:
Tom Hanks has yet again starred in one of the year's best films. After a little film about the AIDS virus called "Philadelphia", Mr. Hanks has been on a terrific film streak. Well his new film, Cast Away is another terrific eye-opener, about a FedEX troubleshooter (Hanks) who gets stranded on an island for four years after his plane crashed into the middle of the South Pacific. Chuck's last words to his fiancÃ©e, Kelly were "I'll be right back". A perfect touch to the film, that tells you of things to come. Chuck now must survive on his own both physically and emotionally without human contact and everyday devices that we all take for granted. The first hour or so after the crash has pretty much no dialogue, until Noland finds a package wash ashore. The package contains a Wilson volleyball. Well after Chuck cuts his hand; in pain he picks up the ball and throws it. It turns out, the blood stain on the ball shaped into a perfect face. Alot has been said about how stupid and unrealistic that a man would actually talk with a volleyball with a face on it for four years. Well I'll tell you something; picture yourself on a deserted island. Got it? Now here's the catch... YOU'RE ALL ALONE! You got absolutely no contact with anybody, and all you got is a volleyball with a face on it. I don't know about you but I'd go insane without anybody or anything to talk with. Wilson was symbolic to the other part of himself. He needed to talk to somebody (or for that matter, something) about the things he's learned in life, ideas, feelings, fears, jokes, stories, and memories. It's normal human behavior. We need some sort of a social life! It's impossible not to express your feelings with something, so he vented with Wilson. Let's also remember that he had a relationship with Wilson for four years! That is a very long time. The Wilson idea is very realistic and a perfect touch to the film.

Well after four years on the island, Chuck goes through many changes: his appearance and more importantly he has become much wiser. Chuck also managed to completely conquer the four of the basic human needs: food, shelter, water, and clothing. The film is about the human spirit and how strong it can become in difficult situations.

Cast Away is probably one of Robert Zemeckis' (Forrest Gump, What Lies Beneath, Back to the Future trilogy) greatest achievements since "Who Framed Roger Rabbit". Robert Zemeckis is one of the most innovative and outstanding young directors and is definitely the future for directors and everyone should keep their eye on him... along with M. Night Shyamalan and David Fincher.

This is definitely one of the best films of the year and will leave you breathless. For those who thought Gladiator was the best film of the year (this means you the Academy), what I ask is, why? Sure Gladiator was a great film, and I liked it alot, but Cast Away has a moral (as did Requiem for a Dream which I personally thought was the best film of the year) and will teach you to respect the things we take for granted like fire, clothing, a place to live, etc... So I believe that the Academy only gives the picture that was most popular the Oscar, and that is quite sad.

Go see the film and learn to respect the things we take for granted.

****1/2 out of ***** 9/10

Title: Why Survive? For self and for the eternal motivator -- love!
Review: The central story, Tom Hanks' character surviving a plane crash, being the sole survivor, and spending four agonizing years surviving on an uninhabited island is well done. After watching the film 3 o4 4 times, some detail jumped out at me that I hadn't previously noticed, or just wasn't paying enough attention. There are two women overshadowing Hanks' spiritual/physical journey. There is Kelly, the love of his life who becomes a "lost love" with the passage of time. Then there is Bettina, first merely a symbol (the orange wings) on the one FedEx parcel that Hanks decides to hang on to in case he gets rescued. Before his ill-fated air trip, the sign on the Texas Ranch says "Tony" and "Bettina". Over the passage of time Tony and Bettina (who we do not see or know) have become uncoupled just as Hanks' character and Kelly are uncoupling because of separation. Hanks is sustained by the pocket watch mounted photo of Kelly and to a lesser extent, by the presence of the "Bettina" parcel. Near the end of the film, when he is back on the mainland, he has to come to terms with the loss of Kelly, while simultaneously if not knowingly opening himself to finding new love with Bettina. Love lost; love found. An interesting juxtaposition. This is, as stated, a more cameo part of the overall story but one which should not be lost sight of--for what can motivate a man to survive against all odds is the possibility of finding new love to replace the one lost?

Title: Great mass entertainment
Review:
The classic Zemeckis-Hanks flick. The kind of movie I knew was good from the first scenes, with the long tracking shot of a FedEx package, when the camera is glued onto it and the focus shifts on Tom Hanks' character. I was sold. And I'm not talking about the plane crash scene which was just impressive. Look at the track records of Robert Zemeckis (before the perfcapt movies) and tell me he's not a good director. The narration here works so well because it's always focused on something, mainly Tom Hanks, and never wavering, and all the drama is channeled through him. When you think about it, there's only 1 character for 1h30 of the movie (unless you count Wilson as a character) and it's never boring.

Only the end felt a little flat, Tom Hanks is basically mute, and we don't really experience how what he's gone through has changed him.

In the end it's basically a very well made and thoroughly researched mass entertainment movie, which of course has these little annoying 'merican narrative things (Tom Hanks is SO good at his job, he loves his wife SO much), but it moved me, so kudos.

Title: Great Hanks performance, but...
Review: You've read the synopses, you know what the movie is about. Let's get to the meat... skip if you wish no spoilers. Tom Hanks did a fantastic job of creating a believable character. His acting was perfect for the role. Up until his eventual rescue the film is excellent. Sure, we could have seen more of his "decline" into more primitive processes, and it would have added to the movie. The roundabout way his suicide attempt is introduced in the movie is effective. The crash is harrowing. His discoveries on the island are phenomenal. His "transformation" into the lean, thousand-yard stare, almost-hopeless primate is wonderful (he seems almost neanderthal in his reaction to the porta-potty piece in the water... loved it). The movie _after_ the rescue missed its mark. Hanks discussion with his friend on the private plane had neither the stilted quality one might expect from someone whose sole partner for 4 years was a punctured volleyball, nor did it have the possibly clamouring quality of someone who is finally around a lost friend. I could expect either, but instead we are treated to a rather bland characterisation. In fact, all of the interactions with others (save the rather emotional monologue to the same friend later) have this detached quality that TO ME seems inappropriate somehow. This is almost painfully true in his interaction with his long-lost sweetie, played by Helen Hunt. My problem is I can't seem to be able to imagine any _real_ people, when placed in the same situation, who would act the way that both of them act. Even the "last chance" part towards the end didn't have that emotion that one would expect in the situation. Anyway, I enjoyed the film, but am still mildly disappointed with the points above. I will still, however, probably buy it when it comes out on DVD. Go figure.

Title: a man that lived by the clock takes a break
Review:
The story line was great and the ads were terrific. I've enjoyed nearly every film made by Tom Hanks. He is an excellent actor, but I was displeased with this film. Hanks still did a fabulous acting job and if as one of the other commentors stated he would be nominated for an award, he still deserves it. This 2 1/2 hour movie could have been cut to 1 1/2 and still carry the same story line.

The reason that I scored this film low is that the second part of the film is so long and leaves you hanging and finally, bored. I actually yawned, wondering if there was anything else to the movie besides him being stranded on the island. There are scenes that show his progression, but what about his family, friends, FedEx and the Federal Government? It didn't even show the flight central (or whatever they call them) losing the plane from the radar and conducting the notifications.

They did a great job showing the transition from being Mr. Busy to Mr. Twiddle-My-Thumbs, but there was a lot left out that would naturally be happening that could have had the audiance reacting or wanting to react to the scenes after the crash. I think adding those other angles or viewpoints would have taken this film from being OK, to great.

Title: Tom Hanks Does It Again
Review:
Robert Zemeckis and Tom Hanks have teamed up again to bring us a thoroughly entertaining new film in `Cast Away'. While `Cast Away' does not bring us the magic that `Forrest Gump' did, but in all honesty what really could, it does however show us the incredible range of actor Tom Hanks. It is hard to believe that this extraordinary actor got his start in such TV shows as `Bosom Buddies'.

Hanks in `Cast Away' spends much of the film alone so very little dialog is used, except in moments of frustration and brief `insanity' where he talks to his new best friend, Wilson, Hanks must rely on his actions to convey his emotions and he does this beautifully! In scene after scene he had me believing & feeling for what he was going through. Even in scenes that could have been ridiculous, i.e. risking his own well being for a volley ball, Hanks made me see the importance of saving this ball and pulled at the heart strings when he was unable to do so.

The movie itself falls short of a classic, with an unsatisfying ending and a wasted Helen Hunt as the girlfriend he left behind, but the real heart of this movie is Hanks and his fight to stay alive and that alone was worth every penny!

Title: This is an excellent film!
Review: In my opinion, this was actually a `film', rather than a `movie'. I liked it anyway. To me, a "film" is a movie where we are supposed to think about things. A "movie" is simply meant to entertain. In this film, we are taken into the world of Chuck Noland, a FedEx employee. We learn that he is his job. Time is his enemy. He loves his girlfriend Kelly, but to be together, they must compare planners. Then, his world changes drastically. He attempts to do things in his usual manner, very quickly. Time teaches him patience. We don't learn about Chuck through dialog as much as we do through the lens. There are scenes in the movie where we feel what the characters in the movie must be feeling, simply by seeing endless ocean and endless prairie. We also see the might of nature in stunning storm tossed seas and powerful winds. If you are patient, Chuck will tell you why he survived and then you will learn if he will survive. If I say anything more, it would spoil it for you. This movie is 2 and a half hours long, but it doesn't feel like a long movie. I honestly didn't notice the time passing. I do recommend this movie, whether you expect a movie to challenge your thinking or are someone that likes to be entertained. If you are like me, you are probably both.

Title: How many endings does one movie need?
Review:
Zemeckis and Broyles deserve credit for a truly original version of a tired concept: Robinson Crusoe, Gilligan's Island, Survivor, etc. The middle (greater) part of the film, set on the island, is extremely watchable, never boring, and often moving. Tom Hanks is so acceptable to all of us as a sort of "everyman," one can't help but fully identify with this character in these circumstances. (Also, I have to mention the plane crash is the most unsettling and, I assume, realistic I've ever seen.)

The one problem with the movie, and I think it actually fatally mars the whole thing, is the ridiculous ending(s) meant to spin some sort of sentimental closure. I counted 5 possible endings, and the thing kept going for 15 more minutes. I think the studio was probably afraid of ending on an uncertain note, so they just kept adding on until they reached the level of maudlin sentimentality they felt appropriate. In actuality, uncertainty would have perfectly matched the tone of Hanks' character at that point in the film.

Title: Not perfect, but wonderful
Review:
I saw 'Cast Away' last night and must say that I was very impressed. The fact that I am a fan of Tom Hanks probably helped me enjoy the film, because I doubt anyone who does not like Tom Hanks would enjoy 'Cast Away' being the fact that he is almost the entire film.

'Cast Away' is far from a perfect film, as there are some minor, and a few major, holes in the story and sadly the script is not always up to scratch. To be honest, I was a little surprised that the film has so many flaws, given the fact that the Australian media have been so full of praise. In my opinion however, Tom Hanks carries the film beyond these flaws and script letdowns, and while Helen Hunt is not given much to do, she is wonderful in the small screen time she has.

The first 25-30 minutes of the film is essentially fairly dull, however it has a certain edge to it created by the viewer already knowing what is install for Hank's character. The plane crash is one of the most amazing things I have ever seen on film. I was actually not looking forward to the plane crash footage because I figured it would be nothing more than something the audience would have to endure before the real story begun. However, it was so good that I actually felt myself tensing up, which really say's something about the footage because I rarely respond like that to anything on screen.

The Âcast away' part of the story is equally brilliant, because it could so easily have been unbearably boring. I think many reviewers on this website are correct in their disliking of the way in which it cuts to Âfour years later', as it does feel as if Zemeckis took the easy way out in this respect. My only other complaint about the Âcast away' part of the story is Hank's escape off the island, which did seem a little rushed in execution and generally not as dramatic (with the exception of one moment, but I won't completely spoil it) as the events that had taken place before. However, this part of the film is by in large incredible, and a work of pure genius from both Zemeckis, but particularly Hanks.

Finally, many reviewers here have complained about the last part of the film, many suggesting that it went on too long. However, I did not find myself bored or restless during the last part of the film because I was generally interested in finding out what happens to Hank's character as he tries to re-enter society. My complaint about the last part has more to do with the script lulls, because the film does not answer some of the bigger questions regarding this transition. However, like all of the weaker spots in the film, Hanks carries the audience past them and it is his presence that makes this one of the best films since American Beauty (released around the same time last year)

I truly hope that Hanks gets his third Oscar for his role in this film, because quite simply, I have not seen a better performance in any film over the last 12 months.

Title: disappointment/suprised/could have been so much better.
Review: There were so many scenes in this film that dropped the ball. Scenes that could have been dramatic. Instead, they went nowhere. For instance...as Hanks waded through the water, cutting his feet on coral. Blood was everywhere...yet no sharks? And, why not switch back to what was happening at home? People were leaving during the film - and NOT COMING BACK. This is no slam against Tom Hanks, for he is truly gifted. But the script clearly had problems. Several scenes could have brought gasps from the audience, brought suspense, drama to the film, instead, the man beside me started snoring. Too many set-ups without going anywhere. This was the very first time that I was disappointed with a Tom Hanks film. In the cave...a skeleton would have worked. Maybe during the crash, Hanks could have been saved by the captain, then when Hanks was safe in the raft, the captain could have been washed overboard and drown in the high seas. Of course, this is just my opinion, but I was just so disappointed in this film. I thought the ending could have been more dramatic and Hunt could have brought up the ring that Hanks had given her before he left. She could have gone back to Hanks, or maybe her husband could have loved Hunt so much that he actually sacrificed his own happiness so Hunt would be happy with the love of her life. Oh well, Sorry. Such talented people involved, yet I went away disappointed. I don't think I was the only one.

Title: A fairly poor movie overall
Review:
I was very disappointed after seeing this movie. The story not being original (see the book "Robinson Crusoe" by Daniel Defoe) I expected much more from the playwright than was offered. I could honestly say that I haven't learned anything from this film that I hadn't already known. Even the moments that were intended to be dramatic and thought-provoking were usually long and cliche; as for the adventure side of the movie, apart from a scene or two at the beginning, the adventure and the thrill are missing almost completely. Far from being a "suspenseful thriller", the movie leaves viewers wanting for more most of the time and eschews improvisation and the potential for action.

In short, if you've read "Robinson Crusoe" or even if you are a little familiar with the story then don't waste your time on this movie. It really isn't worth your time and Tom Hanks's acting cannot make up for the lame scenario.

Title: An introspective look at the thematic implications of Cast Away.
Review:
I am feeling, well, melancholy isn't perhaps the right word, but close. Pensive? Contemplative? I have been in this state for nearly 5 days now, and this is my homage to that feeling--this is my way of capturing it, harnessing it. As thoughts flood into my head I desperately try to write them down as quickly as possible, but surely some will get washed away with the tide.

I have just returned from a movie that has altered, or re-affirmed my view of life and the world. It is my second time seeing Cast Away, and I am undoubtably changed. Not so much changed, but perhaps intensely more aware of what is important in life.

All my days equalling 22 years to this point, have told me one day I would "become," but as I'm growing to learn, you never finish "becoming"--as you learn more and more about life and the world you try things on for size and see how they fit you. It doesn't end--nobody taps you on the head with a magic wand one day and says "ok, you have 'become', now go and live." It is the living that fuels the becoming.

That said, there are definitely defining times or moments when one feels themselves "becoming" faster or closer to who they think they are. This was one such time for me, watching Tom Hanks live out on screen my dream.

I really battle with the idea of who I am. One day I think I know, the next it has changed without warning. Identity is so difficult because you can't have an objective opinion about yourself, yet only you know yourself well enough to determine your own identity. This leads one to the conclusion that perhaps, though moulded by our nurture, it is indeed our nature that is already planned out for us which we reveal piece by piece, with each successive leg of experience and experiences in life.

One think I know for sure is, I am meant for a simple life. Not simple in that I am a simple person, for I am one of the most complex people I know of, but simple as in that is what I crave, long for and have grown up to appreciate. Despite my sometime wild dreams of wealth and prosperity, down deep I realize the wealth I seek is wealth of life, the marrow, the experience, and prosperity in making a difference on the world I touch.

The movie Cast Away has stirred something inside of me I need to remind myself of more often--the value of simplicity, the necessity to re-evaluate what is really important, and how much our antibiotic, commercialistic, technology-driven society brainwashes us into thinking that if we buy into it, we'll fill a void that can truly only be filled by God, and self-knowledge that comes from *truly* living. This kind of living is one virtually unknown to our North American society but it is one based on need and necessity, and not greed and desire. And when it comes down to it, truly all we need to live is faith, sustenance, purpose and above all else, love.

When we stand at the cross roads of life, there are many paths we could take, and only one we will. As Frost suggests, I shall embark on the one least travelled. My life awaits me along the path, not at the end. ****************************

While you may think I haven't told you anything about the movie, this is everything the movie has purged from me.. and so maybe I've told you more than a plot summary could ever do. If you want an opinion, form your own by seeing it, and experiencing it. It may cause you to re-evaluate your self, and your life. Remember, the depth of the movie is only as deep as you allow it to penetrate, and it's strength comes from understanding that it's "Cast Away" and not "Castaway". "I know what I have to do now. I gotta keep on breathing, because the sun will rise in the morning, and you never know what the tide will bring." --Tom Hanks in "Cast Away"

Title: Must watch
Review:
It is a nod to Tom Hanks talent that for the majority of Cast Away the only other object or thing in the movie is a volleyball. I'm sure there will be wags who will glibly compare Cast Away to the likes of "Gilligan's Island" and "Survivor", but, in tone, approach, and overall accomplishment, this atypical Robinson Crusoe tale bears a strong resemblance to one of director Robert Zemeckis' earlier efforts, Contact. No, Cast Away isn't about space or messages from another planet, but, at its core, neither was Contact. Both films ask the same crucial existential question, one that Shakespeare pondered for years: taking all things into account, what does it mean to be human? How do we cope with loss, hopelessness, and isolation, and still find the courage to face the next day? The love and dream of a dead father sustained Jodie Foster's character in Contact. For Tom Hanks' Chuck Noland in Cast Away, it is the promise offered by the smile of his equally absent - and equally beloved - wife-to-be. A magical experience.

Title: Good, but it could have been better...
Review:
The narrative is just fine and Tom Hanks is wonderful as usual. The film fails in structure. All too often frame stories fail somewhere along the line. Either the frame is stronger than the middle, or, as in this case, the middle is stronger than the frame story. The beginning and end could have been reshaped or deleted and the story would have been all the better for it. The frame feels tacked on almost. As I watched it, I felt as if i were watching a great film just screaming to be let out of this miserable structure. And I am of the opinion that if you are going to cast Helen Hunt, you don't waste her time and ours by only using her for a 30 minute role. She is too wonderful an actress for such a minor and thankless role.

Title: A bright, shiny package with nothing inside.
Review:
There is nothing below the shiny surface of this movie -- what did Hanks' character really "cast away?" He finds no perspective on his life or situation other than a similarity to tidal vicissitudes. He discovers no spirituality of any kind - not even when he buries the man who saved his life. He relates to a ball better than he ever did to his girlfriend or to her memory... & what does that teach him? Nothing that we can see. The strengths he is forced to find in his solitude are a mystery to us (besides making fire) & it's therefore a mystery as to how well or how badly these all-important, basic strengths translate to his "real" life, or to his "new" self. So again I ask what was "cast away" - & what was found? His bland relationship with Hunt's character? That's it? Seems he should've discovered, & cast away, a lot more on that island - & therefore returned home a richer man. Are we ever asked what is really hidden in every man's heart, underlying "civilization?" Or what use or meaning there is in a single solitary life? Oddly, no. I found the film sadly, strangely void. A deserted island is so fertile as a dramatic device, & yet it simply framed a film that itself felt deserted.

Title: Excellent production and splendid settings. Good performance.
Review:
The story line was not hard to follow and was very interesting, but it is very hard to stuff any more since it was already 3 hours long. The viewer's imagination was needed to fill in the rest of the sage.

This film was very hard to work on the outdoor sets. The realities of island living are brutal and difficult to portray. Much of the hardships were left out of the film. Anyone who watched Gilligan's Island would have thought otherwise.

Tom Hanks carried the film on his back and did much better than expected. I agree with most other comments about desiring to see more scenes about Chuck Nolans' integration back into society. I expected more makeup work to display a variety of skin diseases, rashes, infections and at least a skin peeling sunburn! The island scenes captured his injuries well and helped the audience with much of the painful side of the experience, especially the bad tooth scene in the cave. The film needed more pain! It was too sterile after the rescue.

Title: better than expected.

Title: Good effort.
Review:
This movie portrays the typical 'stranded-on-a-deserted-island' storyline. I give this movie credit for the following reasons:

1. Realism - while no movie can truly portray an accurate depiction of real life, this movie makes an honorable attempt. A truly believable story overall, but believable in the same way that 'The Old Man and the Sea' is believable... it is so dull that it might actually happen.

2. Creativity - I give this movie a higher rating because of the writers/producers creativity in making everyone's favorite piece of sporting equipment 'Mr. Wilson' an integral part of the plot. Unlike the 'Old Man and the Sea' I mentioned earlier, the leather bound counterpart to the protagonist works much more effectively than a large decaying fish. While the fish is treated more as an object to be worshiped, the volleyball is treated more as a companion, and makes for much better dialouge.

Overall, a good movie. Very respectable performance by Tom Hanks... who incidentally lost a decent amount of weight for his part. Also, this movie is yet another example of his ever-expanding variety of roles and how his characters continue to evolve and mature.

Title: He missed the simplist way of making a fire.
Review:
I found Cast Away enjoyable and thought provoking. But it bothered me that this intelligent and resourceful man missed a simple way to make a fire. He had a flashlight (a Maglite) which provided short lived protection from darkness with its symbolic security of civilization. Eventually, the batteries die and has to work very hard making a fire to feel civilized again. But, if he had removed the front of the flashlight, he could have used it as a lens to concentrate the sun's light and easily have made a flame. The glass cover to his pocket watch and the wrist watch could probably also have served. Since their curves are not as great as the flashlight, it would have taken a little longer.

Title: Chuck Noland, an employee for FedEx, is sent on a business trip that resulted in a plane crash
Review:
Cast Away does an incredible job using cinematography to convey a message. Film makers using extreme long shots to show distance and the enormity of the island. Close shots are also used to make you feel secluded. They are used to make you feel like there is nothing else around except for Chuck and you as you are watching it. The directors did a create job with just casting one actor (Tom Hanks) and using him without dialogs to portray everything that was going on. There were incredible aerial shots of Chuck standing on top of a large cliff that is over the island and ocean to show how massive that the island itself is and how high up that Chuck is. Panning shots were also used very well to make a specific area of land or body of water to seem longer or bigger than it actually is. Symbolism played a big role in Cast Away. It created multiple ideas in an audience's mind of how the movie could go. The use of natural lighting made the overall film quality better.

If you love wondrous, slightly intense dramas then Cast Away is for you. It does not keep you on the edge of your seat but it keeps your mind always thinking ahead about how this story could possibly end out. If you enjoy just a little romance and not an extreme amount you would also enjoy this movie. This movie is for all types of people. It is not over dramatic and girl like. It is for both guys and girls. If you like feeling a part of a setting this movie will give you that exact feel. If you love adventurous movie shots, such as, views from a top of cliffs and underwater then this is a movie you will come out of wanting to watch over and over.

Title: Less action than expected, but a great story...
Review:
Cast Away is an interesting story that forces us to think. There are many great shots and nicely crafted scenes in Cast Away, but what I think distinguishes it from most movies today is its willingness to show us a story rather than tell us what we should think and feel. Although I would have liked to hear more of Hanks' own thought process, we're forced to look inward and see how Hanks' character parallels our life. Following the movie we are forced to reflect how we would act if we were on the Island, what we would do if our only true love was lost for years only to reappear, and how relationships lived inside our heads are often perfect but rarely play out in reality. These all happen here and Zemekis wisely enough doesn't show us how they should be resolved, but simply what happens to Hanks' character and how an everyday man copes with extraordinary circumstances both on and off a deserted island.

Title: Amazing! (Some spoilers)
Review:
Robert Zemeckis has his 4th best film here (behind Forrest Gump, Who Framed Roger Rabbit and Back to the Future) with Cast Away. Sure it might be overhyped and some characters in the film aren't needed (not to mention it depends on the liking of the lead), but when you have Tom Hanks working harder than any actor in a movie this year, it is worth it.

The story follows Hanks as a dedicated fed-ex deliverer who has a fiance (Helen Hunt) and has to leave her Christmas time to go to Asia, but alas, the plane he's on crashes in the water and, dare I say more (well I can because practically everyone saw the all-revealing trailers)? Well, Hanks arrives on a deserted island and then the real fun begins as he survives in a primitive way (probably remenicent of 2001, Hanks' favorite film), and even finds a silent companion named Wilson (a volleyball). That Hanks can communicate with this volleyball, and almost make the ball as a real person with real feelings that is almost like the Silent Bob to his Jay, is one of the films triumphs. The others of course being the whole lot of him on the island and Hanks' performance. If it was someone else, it would not be as successful, but Hanks gives his all and (as usual) pulls through 5 fold delivering one of the years and his best performances. A-

Title: Watchable, yet incredibly flawed
Review: First off, I will agree with anyone who says the performance by Tom Hanks (And most any other actor or actress in this movie) was quite astounding. However, I feel this movie's problems are "What Lies Beneath" (To steal the title from Zemeckis' other film this year). Usually, I am the last person to say a movie is "boring"; oftentimes, my favorite movies are those with a 3-hour+ running time. At times, however, this movie, to be blunt, is BORING. The reason for this is because all the island scenes are strung together one after another; if the movie were to show one or two island scenes and then a scene of what was going on back home (Say, his friends' and families' reactions to the crash or his funeral), and so on, the pacing wouldn't have suffered so greatly. Second, on this island he has food, water, shelter, and so on. So why is he unhappy? Easy - No human contact. This is where Wilson the volleyball's role was so pivotal. Yet everyone in the auditorium, including myself, could not stop laughing. The movie failed on all counts to show Mr. Hanks' character's grief. I kept drawing parallels between the last 45 minutes of this film and David Croenberg's "The Dead Zone". Both feature a character who has been removed from society for a number of years and then is thrown back in, only to find that everything has changed. The movie could've succeeded here. It could've shown in detail what had changed, it could've further allowed Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt to show off their acting chops, it could've shown how the characters dealt with these changes, it could've been a better movie. In 1998's "The Thin Red Line", Terrence Malick proved to be quite a visionary director by showing silence and serenity and how it can get to a person. This probably would've made him the better director for "Cast Away". Alas, we'll never know. All in all, this isn't a bad movie so much as it is a disappointment. It's nice that Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis can make exceptionally good movies; it's just a shame this isn't one of them. ***

Title: What a challenging film
Review:
Very good film and very surprising that Hollywood chose to challenge the viewer so much. This is definitely a film that makes you think ... it sure doesn't present everything up front for the 'lowest common denominator' movie goer as most films do.

I was amazed in reading the comments on this Db that nobody pointed out how much Hanks'character's experience on the island mirrored the centuries of experience of ancient man in the Pacific. The learning to create fire, the way to get fresh water, eventual speech (notice how long on the island Hanks doesn't speak ... only when some of his most basic needs have been met does he move up Maslow's hierarchy), and the creation of his own idol/god in Wilson. His own life depending upon fate and the whim of the tides. The story is that of the evolution of man.

Moreover, take his time on the island and compare it to what he had before he got on that plane. Juxtapose the two and I think the movie makes a strong comment on how far we've come standing on the shoulders of millions of years of evolution. We've forgotten how we got here and the movie attempts to remind us. We're so far into self actualization that we'd all be lost if all our 'stuff' was taken away.

The love story that continues long after the film ends (which is left up to us to create) could be the greatest present this film offers. Helen Hunt's character isn't developed because the viewer isn't supposed to grow too attached to her. We are meant to dwell on what may be down the road for Hanks and White.

All that and the commentary on God or fate (whatever you believe) versus random occurrence. Is there any measure of control exerted by us in our own lives, is there a guiding force, or is it all the natural whim of the universe? This movie really let's you begin to ponder all of this, but doesn't force you to think just one way. I like movies like that.

Title: Thoughtful, brilliant, and original film--a must-see
Review: I saw the Austin premiere of Cast Away yesterday, and have been haunted by it since. It is a profoundly moving film about one ordinary man's struggle for survival, not just of the body but of the heart and mind, at the hands of an indifferent Fate. It is alternately funny, unnerving, gruesome, beautiful, and poignant, and at all times believable. I cannot recall another picture from a major studio this spare in terms of script and style--it is a daring and refreshing movie. Tom Hanks as Chuck makes the story compelling, carrying more than an hour of the picture by himself with little dialogue and no soundtrack besides wind, waves, and rain. The film can be enjoyed purely for the entertainment value of watching Chuck become lost and find his back to civilisation (no spoilers here, folks), or it can be explored for many layers of meaning: about relationships, about destiny, about ingenuity, about inspiration, and about our basic humanity. The movie is not heavy-handed with its message; you take from it what you put into it, and the audience is expected to work at it a bit. Even the title is multi-faceted . . . but don't be daunted. See this movie; see it many times, as I plan to do.

Title: It's not a movie about merely surviving, but really living.
Review:
This movie isn't called "Castaway", as in someone who's lost on a desert isle, it's "Cast Away", as in something that has been discarded with time. Chuck Noland never wanted to "commit the sin of turning his back on time" when, in fact, time turns its back on him. This isn't a movie about merely surviving a four-year imprisonment on a deserted island, but about whether that survival is worth it. It doesn't take long for Chuck to figure out if he can survive or not, but it takes him the entire four years to decide that that is not enough.

Chuck Noland's life is taken away from him twice. Both times he has to rebuild and discover a new reason to live. He learns, through these ordeals, that it is alright to turn your back on time, but to never let the moment pass you by.

Title: Disappointing
Review:
I was looking forward to an inspiring plot and a unique role for Hanks, but this movie was disappointing. Though the film was over two hours in length, I couldn't help but feel that a lot of content had fallen gracelessly to the cutting-room floor. Time as a concept seemed to flip-flop senselessly, particularly when Hanks' first few compelling and frightening weeks on the island abruptly end and we are informed (with an awkward subtext) that four years has transpired, leaving Hanks lean, mean, and slightly demented.

Some scenes with his "co-star" Wilson were touching. Others were contrived. And Hanks' pathetic, throaty cries as Wilson metaphorically drifts away reminded me more of his character in 'The Money Pit' than anything else. It was hard to take him seriously. And I won't even mention the silliness of Hanks' cetacean buddy, who seemed to magically appear when he was needed most.

Finally, there is Helen Hunt, who seems to be the flavor-of-the-moment in Hollywood, but in this film she is poorly cast. Her performance lacked the true grief, desperation and elation her character should have demonstrated.

Overall, this movie was disappointing. I expected a more riveting performance from Hanks, but the film's editors and writers should accept a greater share of blame for the oft-contrived shallowness of what should have been the best film of the year.

See it, but wait for the video.

Title: Zemeckis does it again.
Review: My favourite Zemeckis films have always been Contact and Forrest Gump. Now his new film Cast Away is added to that list. Cast Away is the ultimate Man vs. Nature epic. This films starts off with Chuck Noland,(Hanks) a Fed Ex executive who takes his job very seriously in Moscow pushing everybody to make their deliveries on time you find out alot about his character in the way he handles his job. He is a person who always has to be on time. When he returns home to Memphis you meet Kelly Frears (Hunt)who is Noland's girlfriend. During a dinner party with family and friends Noland is unexpectedly paged and has to go to somewhere off the east coast of asia to deliver some mail. Hanks and Hunt quickly exchange christmas gifts in the car on the way to the airport. During the very realistic and intense airplane crash into the Pacific Ocean Hanks finds himself stranded on a uninhabited island. The movie takes a daring turn here. The film becomes a one man show as Hanks finds himself stranded. This could make or break the movie for you. Hanks now does what he does best to make this a very entertaining one man show. During his stay on this island you will laugh, cry, and most importantly think about what is in store for this very entertaining character. The comic relief comes from a volleyball named Wilson with a face painted on it with Hank's blood. Cast Away is really everything the summers blockbuster The Perfect Storm was not. I didnt really feel for the characters in perfect storm. Hanks pulls off the role of Chuck Noland magnificently. The cinematography make you feel like you are with Hanks on the island. And best of all Robert Zemeckis's directs this film with so much genius and poise he becomes one of the best at what he does again.

Title: A real waste
Review: This movie had the potential to be truly great. A great cast, great special effects, and an original plot were all in place. Unfortunatley, the execution and the details were poor and it seemed as if the script was written in a rush without any thought. Tom Hanks' character finds himself on a deserted island after a plane crash. From then on he acts as a man with no brain. Upon finding numerous FedEx packages washed up on shore, he stacks them up and opens them days later, including one that he NEVER opens!!! Upon finding a flashlight, he sets it down, while on, and promptly falls asleep, letting the batteries burn out. Left with a small rubber raft, he takes it out into the obviously huge waves, puctures the raft and his leg in the process. He does manage to produce fire, but is then seen four years later eating raw fish. I guess the fire thing got old, huh? After being on the island FOUR YEARS, he gets the idea to BUILD A BOAT. Only four years to think of that. Intertwined in all this is an ongoing conversation with a freaking VOLLEYBALL. He finally builds the boat and gets out into the open sea. He loses the volleyball and weeps uncontrollably, and then decides to throw away his oars and lay there and give up. (Funny how the volleyball is everything, but those oars don't mean a whole lot.) Miraculously he is found and the movie grinds to an end. By the end I was so frustrated I wished he had died.

Title: Very nice indeed

Title: Is it "Cast Away" or "Castaway"?
Review:
This is an interesting, stimulating movie. I don't think I would be spoiling any part of the plot by telling you that the middle third of the film should be titled "Castaway." Hanks' character is stranded on a deserted isle and we experience his efforts to survive. This portion of the film IS interesting, but I thought it went on too long.

Now what follows may spoil the outcome, something the trailers (in uncharacteristic fashion) have not. The most intriguing portion of the film is the last third, when Hanks' character returns to modern society and then is forced to confront being cast away (two words). This is the portion of the film where we really begin to empathize with the main character. Most of us have not had to face nature one-on-one, but all of us have had to face some form of rejection, or being cast away. Zemekis could have made a truly Oscar caliber movie (though I don't doubt that this will receive a nomination) if he had focused on this all too human experience, rather than the intricacies of raft construction.

Title: Slightly shallow, but a good ride.
Review:
This is a GREAT film. Being that the majority of films of 2000 were not that great, this is a shoe-in for multiple Oscar nominations.

Tom Hanks gives a great performance, really making us feel as though we're there with him... as though our fates are entwined with his. His ability for acting shines in this role.

The greater part of the movie rests in mostly silence, as we watch Hanks' character, Chuck, struggling to live on the tiny island which has become his prison. What's interesting about this is that it rips away all the advances and advantages we as a human race have gained, leaving Chuck to learn all over again how to survive.

Rarely have I been actually hurt when I've seen a character on screen experience pain. One scene in particular which makes the audience cry out is when Chuck loses Walter. I doubt there was one person in the theater that wasn't hurt... wasn't hoping against hope that Hanks would get him back, and was almost in tears when he didn't.

Granted, the plot of this film is not complex, and does not require much thought, but that's not a bad thing. Tom Hanks' acting ability turns what could have been a mediocre role into one of depth, making the viewer sympathise with every hardship he must endure.

One thing I've heard many times over is how bad the ending is. Why? Because it's not 'happily ever after?' It is NOT a warm and cozy ending... it's not made to make us feel good inside. It's realistic. And to those who scoff and Hanks' sadness, you've failed to really FEEL his character. Put yourself in his shoes. How would you feel?

Want a funny movie? See "Dude Where's My Car?" Want a movie with a happy ending? See "Gladiator." Want an emotional movie to envelop you and truly tie your feelings into knots? See this one.

You will not be disappointed.

Title: It's about DIVORCE
Review:
A remarkable film, truly inspired and amazingly executed. This is no "teenager" movie! You have to be wise enough to appreciate life, love and loss... in short you must have LIVED to understand it. Most of the viewing crowd (young and old) hasn't the wisdom and will not understand even 10% of this movie, all they can get out of it is the superficial.

If you didn't understand The Green Mile in all of it's deliciously complicated splendor, you will fail to undertstand Cast Away... yes, I mean "Cast Away", not "Castaway". But for those of you who have gone through the pain of IMMEASURABLE LOSS, you WILL understand.

I said it's about divorce, because that is the journey of loss I related to. Some of the more obvious symbology that alludes to this thesis are the divorce certificate in the FedEx box (his job leads to a divorce), the dead pilot's family picture (there is no wife in the photo), the island represents his despair and loneliness at being "cast away" by his wife, but at the same time the island is a sanctuary which allows him to experience and reveal his true "self". Further, the island (lonliness and separation) feeds, protects and cares for him over time so he can grow strong to meet the challenge of the waves (change/journey). Finally, the raft represents the promise of a new life, the volleyball the old self, the paddles represent letting go and accepting God/Fate/reality, and the whale is the confidence that there is a spirit/guide/guardian/angel watching over us (all we have to do is listen).

The movie is beautifully made and has a beautiful message... SURVIVING LOSS. Whether that loss is the loss of a loved one because of divorce or through physical death, this movie is about surviving the greatests depths of despair, and surviving our inner psychological worlds ... not our physical worlds.

Those of you who have, will know what I mean.

John

Title: Thought Provoking
Review:
I don't know what you've heard but most of the critics are raving while many ordinary folks seem to be rather disappointed. I read one review by a member of the public who was moaning about a poor script, god only knows what he was expecting when it's a story about a guy stuck for years on his own on an island!!

Anyway to state the obvious and provide some perspective this is not a special effects movie, but the scenery is impressive and the cinematography is quite often excellent. The script is of course thin but the small amount of character interaction is largely convincing and you can relate to the two main characters.

To sum up, this movie is trying to make you think and sympathise, if you just sit and stare at the screen with brain disengaged you will either fall asleep or just get incredibly bored.

The film wasn't exactly what i had expected but the more i thought about it afterwards the more i realised how good a film it was. In terms of making you step back and assess your life this film is almost as good as It's a Wonderful Life, it's just a shame that the effect wears off.

Title: nothing more than a boring commercial
Review: Let me start with the positive stuff about this movie: The music is (like in Forrest Gump) absolutely great and always fits to the scenes. But that's about it. The main bad thing is, that this movie had the chance of being good. But not one of the things that could have been interesting was brought up. At first we have a guy who finds himself on an island. But just after he finds out how to survive physically, we read "4 years later" as a subtitle. His whole psychological development is presented with the fact, that he talks to a volleyball named...(I won't take part in the product placement, that p... me off during the whole movie.) I mean, we got a guy with no one to talk to 4 years, with no courts or people judging his actions, that's stuff you can make a great movie out of (something which also challenges the actor instead of just having him lose 50 pounds). Ok, we will not see what he did during this 4 years, the story carries on. He now decides that 4 years are enough and that he wants to go back. And then, there's another situation that could have been interesting, but he also finds back into real life after 4 days or a similar period. I have no problem with his decision to go on with his life without his wife, but his period of inner struggle is so short in this movie, so that you can not appreciate his decission as much as it deserves. Besides all this, imagine the movie would have had all that stuff. Could you the have enjoyed it? Not me, as long as half of the time I can always read Fed-E... on the screen. This is something so sad, as Tom Hanks should have enough money, to act in movies with less product placement and a bigger stress on the story. I guess I just expected way too much of a director actor couple that once made an awesome movie named "Forrest Gump".

Title: Gripping, moving, eye-opening
Review:
This film made me understand how art was "invented", how man discovered the usefullness of tools, why man gives such immense mythical sense to the symbols he invents. Cast away on a desert island, alone in the most absolute meaning of the word (no other animate creature (accept fish) ever comes across Hanks' path during his stay on the island), jet-flying, hard-working Hanks is reduced to the state of primitive man. There is nothing around him which can help him survive. His landing on the island is his DAY ZERO. However, fate first comes to his rescue when he is unsuccessfully trying to break the hard shell of a coconut with a piece of what appears to be volcanic rock. The rock splinters, but what remains in his hand is a piece of rock which has a sharp edge...a knife!! From then on he can split open his coconuts with ease. (It seems that coconut and fishes are the only things Hanks eats on the island.)

Hanks seems to be extremely scrupuolous in his profession. He only opens the packages which drift into the island with him after a few days, not at once. In one of them he finds a volleyball, for which he cannot figure out any use.

Sometime later, Hanks angrily hits this volleyball with his hand full of blood after he cuts himself while trying to get some fire burning. The red hand-shaped stain on the ball appears to Hanks as if it were a face...and so it becomes his friend and companion on the island...Wilson! The attachment Hanks develops to this symbol will be very evident later on in the film.

I believe that there are just good films, and bad films, nothing else. This is a good film.

Hanks has reached another dimension in his acting, and really I doubt whether there is any other actor around nowadays who can so easily adapt himself to such varied roles as being a simpleton in Forrest Gump, an astronaut in Apollo 13, and a modern-day Robinson Crusoe in this film. Marvellous!

Well, what can I say? I think this comment is long enough as it is! GO SEE THE MOVIE!

Title: Didn't know if I liked it or not as I walked out
Review:
Then as I was driving home and thinking about the movie a little more, I realized that this movie, unlike any other movie I had ever seen) kept me glued to my seat without having a disaster around every corner. The two movies to which I got dragged this past year ended up being the two best movies I saw. Gladiator was great, with Maximus's fall from glory and rise to victory once more... and then I went to see Castaway.

Castaway managed to keep my intention without the tenseness of a movie such as Jaws. It was so refreshing to sit back and enjoy a great movie without disaster after disaster. Chuck walks through the water on the rocks with blood gushing from his leg... no shark attack. He stands on the edge of the rock cliff... no slip of the toe to send him over. He sails out to sea once more on his makeshift raft... he's still laying on that raft when he gets rescued.

Yes, a movie can be refreshing, exciting and riveting without all those movie disasters we've all come to expect. Two thumbs up to Hanks and Zemeckis for a wonderfully made film. I would pay $10 to see it again.

Title: hope is in the box
Review:
I liked the movie! Tom had my undivided attention for 145 minutes and I am a critic of the Survivor concept! I think the movie is so popular because everyone can relate to the isolation, loss, confusion and despair that life can offer. Tom had to decide what to do at year #3 when he was at the pinnacle and when he saw Helen Hunt after 5 years away. He had to find a way to move on even though it was as difficult as living on the island.

I realize there were many rational questions. Why wouldn't he open a box after 4 1/2 years of looking at it? How could he survive without a good supply of fresh water? How could he make it on a raft ( even though the island is only 25 miles north of Nada in Fiji!!!!). They did actually have to stop filming several times to let boats pass!! I think it is a testament of the human spirit and a great movie!!

Title: could a good movie kill us?
Review:
first of all, i have to advise that my english writing is not fluent as i would like. in the second place, i think that loneliness as well as fear of living are concepts not easy to be filmed. well, nobody says that CAST AWAY is a masterpiece, but also i've seen that nobody made a proper objection in this list. i'm afraid that there was superficiality of arguments and too much criticism by the people who stuck on things such as the marketing plane of fedex or the actors role in this movie. i struggled rather a lot in my life, and i still feel completely alone: there isn't a family, a friend, a job, a work or a religion that could calm or satisfy me. this feeling doesn't leave me a second in life and i think also that doesn't exist a remedy to this. never it will be. the final ppp of tom hanks could be a plausible answer to who understand what i have affirmed before. you can't fight it, so why don't you accept it? in addition, this film got all the faults of hollywood industry's films: a budget too big, many "commercials" in it, and so on. but it gives a strong, really strong, sensation, that never let me quiet during the film: feeling of angst. this "artificial" and commercial film can give me the same sensation i had during the worse moments in my life so that i feel worried for two reasons mainly: the first is, how long establishment could manipulate feeling and emotions and secondly what they would to achieve. spectators, especially young people, are gonna be more and more disillusioned of this kind of "stories", and that is a pity, really. i say that is a pity because this side of industry is gonna "kill" every part of good feeling or mood inside us. anyway, i appreciated this film, more than it was expected.

7/10
