Title: Good Effort
Review:
A brief scan over the premise of this movie brings of concern. Can one man really be entertaining for all that time? How interesting can four years on an island be?

However, I was pleasently surprised, but not overly. Tom Hanks manages to keep your attention, his subtle but significant characted journey is absorbing. The various tasks he must carry out to stay alive are interesting - perhaps only academically and not dramtically. A sense of humour prods the story along.

The direction, for me, is what saves the movie however. Instead of the bright colours of a dream like island, we see shades, pastels. Infact the island is rather grim. Time is used wonderfully, from the fast paced world to the timelessness and lonelyness are expertly portrayed. Silence, black screens, both forgotten devices are used to great effect here. Even the 'four years later' although perhaps cliche, perhaps a little lazy, gives the feeling of nothingness that helps us to feel his isolation.

Although a little too long, perhaps not a master piece, this film has a great deal to offer in its details. Daring in superfical minimalism, and deeply considered beneath the surface, this film will be enjoyed by those who like to work hard with their viewing.

Title: Hanks at his best!
Review:
Judging from other comments already posted, 'Cast Away' has touched as many people as it has left others mildly indifferent. I watched it in the cosiness of my living room, on a pretty smart digital wide screen TV, and found it riveting.

It is a bit long and disjointed, and the least that could be said is that the transitions between consecutive periods in the movie are too abrupt. I guess this can happen when one tries to cover several years in a two-and-a-half hour piece, but the lack of smooth transitions destroys the rhythm of the movie.

So why did I find it riveting? First and foremost, Tom Hanks makes an outstanding Robinson Crusoe. Credible from the first minute to the last, he adds to a great acting performance the physical prowess of changing body shapes. One minute a chubby, over-fed executive, the next a survivor close to starvation.

The credibility of his acting brings out one of the main messages of the movie: Corporate America and the pseudo-comfort it creates (but which comfort does Chuck Noland enjoy when travelling from continent to continent in the back of a FedEx aircraft?) mainly serves the purpose of alienating human beings by destroying their relationship to nature.

Ok, some of you will find this statement far-fetched, and Chuck Noland certainly did not crash his plane to enjoy a return to nature. However, I took the contrast between a life in the fast lane and the painstakingly slow pace of survival as a reminder that we should not rely on appearances too much, it doesn't always matter if things happen a few minutes too late.

Beyond the thought-provoking aspects of the movie, I enjoyed some superb photography and scenery, as well as a good plane crash scene. What I wasn't impressed with: too many FedEx signs around - but then, this is corporate America and Hollywood.

Title: All that you can't leave behind
Review:
I saw Tom Hanks sell me this movie for the second time this previous saturday evening. When you watch a man 'cast away' every major component of his life... one by one... clothes,body fat, human contact, comfort, the pressure of time... a portion of sanity... and then see whats left behind.

The first act plane crash is phenomenal. You will NEVER take your shoes off in an airplane again... or be without a Leatherman tool. :-) When Chuck first lands on the island; i was made to feel like the island itself is a creature... a being... a thing that imprisons... it KEEPS you. On the horizon you COULD be free... but you CAN'T GET there. And you watch Chuck. Chuck is REAL. And so are His frustrations, his pain, his discomfort & his joy in triumph!!When he makes fire... I shouted with him. I, too, find myself wanting to get back to Kelly... to hear a human voice... to be warm at night... to not be thirsty anymore. Chuck's numerous transformations make me feel like i went through them with him. During the second act, after four years has passed... it felt like chuck had crawled into a cave... and what was left was "all that he couldn't leave behind" or throw away. Just ... surviving. Staying alive. Then one day the tide brings in his way off. In this film you will watch a man CHANGE. Tom Hanks makes me believe in a character like never before in a film. I BELIEVE him. I BELIEVE he has 'thrown overboard' every thing that was of no use to him in order to survive, in order to LIVE. "WhatEVER it takes to live" was what i thought about as i left the theater... and to ENJOY your life, and enjoy every LITTLE thing. Ice. Sheets. A cup of HOT coffee. Human touch. MUSIC! What if i couldn't listen to music for 4 years??? A kiss from a woman! ( again... 4 years? )Savoring every last good thing in my life. In the word's of U2, this film challenged me to, in my own life, throw overboard the worthless junk that will hinder me, and keep "all that i can't leave behind" ... and enjoy. Go see it. wait. And then see it again. *** By the way... ( and this is seen in the previews) When Chuck says at the beginning of the film;"We live or we die by The Clock!"... he has a pager with a clock, a digital watch, clocks in the warehouse etc.... and at the end ... notice he wears no watch.

Title: The script is an overlooked gem
Review:
Everyone knows about Tom Hanks, Zemeckis's string of huge successes, Wilson the Volleyball, the beautiful scenery, etc. But what stands out to me about "Cast Away" after 20+ years is William Broyles's script.

You're thinking, wait, there's almost no words for much of the film! Right, but when you dig into the script and pay attention to it and to the plot, what you find is a surprisingly profound examination of the concept of time in modern vs. Pre-modern society. You can view the whole movie as a man's transformation, through great pain, into a life that is a rejection of the every-second-matters mania that drives global businesses while also making time spent with loved ones, even friends, fleeting and fragmented.

Broyles gave us a big clue with his title for the script: "Cast Away." Where did that title come from? Why isn't it "Castaway," the normal spelling for someone stranded on an island? I pondered over this for years, and finally realized that it's from the famous passage from Ecclesiastes 3 in the Judeo-Christian scriptures, i.e. For everything there is a season (or "Turn! Turn! Turn!" by The Byrds, same thing). Verse 6:

"A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to *cast away*"

And there you have it: "Cast Away" is, at its core, a meditation on time. Those who find the film boring completely miss the point.

Review:
Tom Hanks did a splendid job in this film. It took guts to do all that was required from the start to the finish = from gaining all that weight and then letting it "fall off" as the film progressed, to being basically the sole character, having the entire film rest upon his shoulders from his performance. We learned lessons right along with him; and his character's dedication to his job held him together and gave him something to hold onto; after all, he DID deliver that package that he held onto for all those years ! Now THAT'S dedication !!! I loved the film ; watched it 3 times and I'd watch it again !

Title: Castaway: stuck on an island an stuck in time
Review:
Tom Hanks portrays Chuck, a Fedex businessman with a hectic schedule and lofty ambitions. Although it is a really emotive film, it moves more slowly than a sloth on steroids.

Chuck Nolan is in Moscow trying to quickly spread Fedex's magic as a harried businessman with a full schedule. After an incredible plane accident compared to the rest of the film, he joins a flight home. He is imprisoned on an island.

The pace of the film is incredibly slow, with one scene taking two minutes when ten seconds would have sufficed to achieve the same effect. This film could have reached the top 5 with a different director, bye bye Robert Zemeckis. The FedEx logo was seen in almost every shot throughout the 2 hours and 23 minutes of the FedEx advertisement. A Many of the scenes consist solely of Chuck's locket or a random FedEx parcel with an upset Chuck. There is no drama, just one big issue: being stranded on an island! The movie becomes even more agonisingly slow as a result. What occurs after that, according to the ambiguous ending? As there is no tension, it is hardly a cliffhanger; rather, it is more like the movie ran out of money before it could finish.

He is alone and gradually becoming insane, which is one of the film's most compelling emotional elements. Everyone is moved when he befriends a volleyball named Wilson; this is perhaps the only reason I would see it again. The only real improvements to the film come from Wilson and the plane accident. #JusticeForWilson

Overall, this film should be condemned to remain in the 2000s; if my children wanted to watch it, I would disown them. The survival action genre has been ruined by this film, which makes Bear Grylls look like a girl scout! Go ahead and watch it if you want, but be prepared for your popcorn to vanish before the action begins. My suggestion: Burn everything, keep the next generation from it.

Title: Movie Review
Review:
This movie is about a man who gets stranded on a deserted island. This character is named Chuck, played by Tom Hanks. Chuck works at FedEx flying from country to country making sure that packages get to their destination in the shortest amount of time possible. A couple of days before Christmas he was forced to go on a business trip. As everyone knows that it is always when things are going well that they are bound to go wrong sooner rather than later. Right before he boards the plane he proposes to his girlfriend Kelly, who is played by Helen Hunt. It is on that flight that things go bad. The plane gets trapped in a storm and the pilots are not able to communicate to others through the radio. Somehow after the plane crashing into the ocean, Chuck miraculously survives. Unfortunately the pilots were not as lucky. Eventually while floating on the planes emergency raft, Chuck wakes up to realize that he is on a deserted island in complete loneliness. He then makes a very strong effort to stay alive using every survival skill known to him. He gathers all of the FedEx packages that are washed up onto the beach. At first he plans to keep all of them closed until somebody showed up. Later in the movie he realizes that he might never be found. So he opens up all of the packages except for one and in one of those packages was his new friend: Wilson brand volleyball that he named "Wilson".

This movie does an excellent job with the picture and sound. The writers and editors do a great job in making this movie interesting since it is all about one man stuck on an island. Tom Hanks does a tremendous job playing the role of Chuck. It is especially challenging to play this part since there is barely any dialogue. Because of this the writers and editors has to emphasize other aspects. For example, the sound of nature took the biggest role in this movie. There was not one second where you could not hear the sound of the waves crashing into the sand. In this movie Chuck grew as a person and fought for his life every single day. What kept him motivated was his fiancÃ©e Kelly. One of the most brilliant aspects of this movie was Wilson. The volleyball that kept him company, kept him motivated, and eventually became his best friend. Apart from adding more to that story, Wilson also helped bring in more dialogue into the movie. In the end of the movie there is an interesting romantic twist that you would have never imagined. This is all explains why this movie is one of the best movies ever made.

Title: Survivor
Review: Once again Hanks makes a smashing hit with the critics and at the box office with his Film "Cast Away." "I'll be right back," says Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks), to his girlfriend Kelly Frears (Helen Hunt) right after he gives her a ring box hinting a marriage proposal when he returns from his business trip. Only Chuck didn't return until four years later. "Cast Away" is a film of love and survival that resides on the shoulders of Chuck Noland. Chuck is a FedEx system Engineer who travels around the world to teach the importance of a speedy delivery to other FedEx couriers. During a flight, his plane hits a thunderstorm that sends it into the Pacific Ocean. Only Chuck survives. He floats in a life raft to a deserted island with only a few FedEx packages as the only remains. Robert Zemeckis did an excellent job directing while Hank's did an even more excellent job acting out two-thirds of the movie on his own. The only dialogue during this time is when Chuck speaks to Wilson. Wilson, the volleyball, comes from a left over FedEx package and has a face drawn on with Chuck's blood. This movie has an emotional tug and it makes us feel just like we are on the island with Chuck. The ending to the movie isn't the normal perfect ending. It has a real life twist of how people move on with their lives even after a tragedy. This movie is a survival drama we should not miss.

Title: Brilliant portrayal of one man's struggle with solitude...
Review:
"Cast Away" is an excellent portrayal of one man's determination to stay alive, no matter how impossible the situation seems to be. After a freak storm sends a Federal Express plane down in the Pacific Ocean, Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) is the only survivor. Clinging to an emergency raft that he found during the plane's decent into the raging ocean, he eventually drifts onto a deserted tropical island. He quickly learns how to survive in this harsh environment but reality sinks in as he realizes that there can be no rescue from this isolation. After a while, Chuck begins to lose what sanity he has left and befriends a volleyball (Wilson) that he accidentally imprints with his bloody hand. Chuck and Wilson remain on this island for three long years until the winds and tides are right for getting his handmade boat off the island.

Hanks does a brilliant job of bringing to life the agony and despair of being the sole human operator in complete isolation. His monologues with Wilson (which he actually believes is communicating with him) keep him focused on making the boat and his undying love of his wife (Helen Hunt) keep driving him to strive against all odds.

I give this movie 9 and a half stars out of 10, because the ending is a little too open.

Title: Deepest film ever from a Taoist perspective (SPOILERS)
Review:
It is all all about shedding the ego. Chuck has a HUGE ego. Not in the sense that he is a jerk or selfish but in the Buddhist way definition of ego: he think he can control everything (ego) and lives totally in time (ego) and puts his job first, because it creates a sense of order (ego) and so on. He puts more stock in giving Kelly a ring at the car than staying behind to be with her for the holidays because, to the Ego, a ring is more important than the relationship. Ego loves symbols and form more than what is behind them. However, the universe endlessly tests his ego by showing him that he is actually powerless. Which he cannot accept. First, he is in Russia and he gets the clock that he sent himself and it took many days to get there and shows him he is out of control. But he makes that everyone else's problem and even steals a kids bicycle to speed up the package delivery. he is willing to do anything to regain control rather than accept any powerlessness. Then his friends wife is dying and he , again , can't accept his own powerlessness and suggests a doctor to "fix this thing". Which, of course he can't. It's death. Since Kelly knows what he loves best, she gives him a watch because time is the only thing he finds valuable (ego). And then the plane goes down. On the island he is endlessly shown how powerless he is, and again wont accept it. He cant make fire, he cant eat, his tooth is decayed. But he wont accept it, he keeps trying to overcome it with reason. He still is collecting packages. Finally, he cant even kill himself correctly. At this point, is his first glimpse at a higher self because, later, when he tells the story to his friend, he say that when he realized that he couldn't even kill himself, a "warm feeling came over him" and stayed with him. This is his first moment of enlightenment, a forced realization that he is totally powerless and thus a moment of forced alignment with something higher. Then it takes four more years of ego battering before he has let go of ego enough internally to be able to just float where the winds take you (as Lao tze says) ... literally.. as a sail comes in.

But when he gets home, his dormant ego flares up again, as it tries to control the uncontrollable, he still hasn't totally learned. So he tries to get Kelly back instead of accepting the situation. thus he is still on the island in his head which is a metaphor for separateness. "No man is an island" The island IS Ego itself.

in the third act, every time his ego flares up and he is trying to control things again ... there is a clock in the background. he is still stuck in time. Again, his ego is pummeled and he must accept his own powerlessness. And then finally, BOOM, it really all comes at once. he lets go. He accepts his own total powerlessness totally and gets in a car and gets to a crossroads having no idea, for once in his life, where he is going. At which point, his angel arrives. His angel tests him one last time. She tells him that to the right is Flagstaff but back the way she is going is "a whole lot of nothing" In the end, he looks back toward nothingness (the direction she is going" and we know he is going to choose the road to nothingness instead of the known destination of Flagstaff, because he has released his ego, accepted powerlessness. He is now capable of drifting powerlessly toward nothingness which is really not nothing at all, it is an alignment with the Universe. Especially so, because the cute girl with the wings lives in that direction and they may fall in love. One last great thing here. When he went to her ranch to leave the package. She has removed the Name "Dick" from "Dick and Bettina" and this now, it only says "Bettina" . From a symbolic perspective, the "Dick" (male organ/ ego) has been removed which represent man and power and only the feminine power is left, the return of the feminine power is associated in Joseph Campbell as mans realignment with God. Bettina which in Hebrew means "God's Promise". And finally, he stand on a cross. (crossroads) resurrected. Wow.

Moral of the story: To shed the ego, totally accept your powerlessness. You will be tested again and again till you genuinely do this. When the ego is shed, then the true self, the one aligned with the Universe and God. Can emerge and take you where you need to go as you are now part of the whole.

Title: Castaway merits a closer look...
Review: Like a Shakespearean play, the different layers of the story cannot be taken in from a one-time viewing of Castaway. I was looking for a specific film example of some of the "Hero-Quest" plot points from Joseph Voggler and picked up this movie for a second viewing. I ended up watching it again with my five year-old son. When Wilson floated away, my son began to cry. Then I began to cry! Damn, my kid got it, and I had missed it. My son understood how "real" an imaginary friend is because he was still a child. Hanks has a rebirth on the island and is stripped down to an infantile state. He becomes a child once again. His entire re-evolution is fascinating. I have watched it at least 8 times since and pick up little pieces that I had not caught before. Like a Shakespearean play, there are layers to this one... Just because the film isn't obvious does not make it "slow." It's amazing what we expect from movies. I expect a story! This is a story of becoming a human being and learning to live a genuine life. I love it, and still tear up. Give it a second viewing. Look at the symbolism, gestures, and expressed emotions. Pay attention to the details (like the "birthday card"). Almost a perfect story! Some people simply won't get it. I think even the main character (Nolan at the beginning of the film) would be too "deadened" to understand it... It is only through his "tragedy" that he becomes a true observer of the gift that life is. That might even be one of the layers. Bravo!!!

Title: Cast Away plot and theme
Review:
Cast Away was released in 2000. Some are the main characters are Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks), Kelly Frears (Helen Hunt), and Ramon (Paul Sanchez). This film mainly revolves around the main character, Chuck, who gets stranded on an island after his plane crashes into the ocean. This film shows how he tries to survive on this island and try to get himself rescued. The film shows how hard it can truly be to try to survive and the emotional toll it would have one someone. Of course you have to watch the film to figure out whether Chuck survives this situation or not.

The theme of Cast Away is pretty straight forward. It is one that shows human survival when we are forced to try and survive or die. This theme focuses on the idea of the struggle for human dignity. Chuck is put in a position of disadvantage and dealt a bad hand when he gets stranded on the island. He is fighting against tremendous odds for his survival. There are also several other films that have a similar theme to Cast Away's theme. 127 Hours is one film that has a similar theme to Cast Away's theme. The main character gets dealt a bad hand when getting stuck in the canyons with his arm crushed and stuck. His is at a disadvantage and fighting against tremendous odds for his survival just like Chuck was in Cast Away.

There are a couple of film techniques that have relevance to the film's theme. One technique is lighting. There is a darker lighting during most of the movie, which helps show the significance of the theme. If the lighting was bright during the whole film, then it would be harder to portray the significance of this theme. Sunny and bright usually means happiness. You wouldn't want the audience to feel OK and happy during the movie, you want them to feel sad, nervous, anxiety, fearful at times. This way the audience can have a feeling of being there and have a sense of reality of what is going on in the film and about the theme.

The second technique is camera angle. The camera angles changes from the viewer seeing Chuck and his surroundings to seeing what Chuck is seeing, like they are looking through his eyes. Interchanging between these camera angles really gets the audience in tune with Chuck and what he is possibly feeling. Getting the audience involved like this really helps get the theme of this movie across to the viewers. This makes the theme very straight forward. A theme of survival against all odds is a great theme that most audience members enjoy and it works great for Cast Away.

Title: Final part should be better
Review:
Robert Zemeckis has his 4th best film here (behind Forrest Gump, Who Framed Roger Rabbit and Back to the Future) with Cast Away. Sure it might be overhyped and some characters in the film aren't needed (not to mention it depends on the liking of the lead), but when you have Tom Hanks working harder than any actor in a movie this year, it is worth it.

The story follows Hanks as a dedicated fed-ex deliverer who has a fiance (Helen Hunt) and has to leave her Christmas time to go to Asia, but alas, the plane he's on crashes in the water and, dare I say more (well I can because practically everyone saw the all-revealing trailers)? Well, Hanks arrives on a deserted island and then the real fun begins as he survives in a primitive way (probably remenicent of 2001, Hanks' favorite film), and even finds a silent companion named Wilson (a volleyball). That Hanks can communicate with this volleyball, and almost make the ball as a real person with real feelings that is almost like the Silent Bob to his Jay, is one of the films triumphs. The others of course being the whole lot of him on the island and Hanks' performance. If it was someone else, it would not be as successful, but Hanks gives his all and (as usual) pulls through 5 fold delivering one of the years and his best performances. A-
